baseline: It is supported by the Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation, with 100 million being the most common estimate used from The Black Book of Communism despite some of the authors of the book distancing themselves from the estimates made by Stephen Courtois.

prompts: Various museums and monuments have been constructed in remembrance of
baseline: Various museums and monuments have been constructed in remembrance of the victims of Communism, with support of the European Union and various governments in Canada, Eastern Europe, and the United States.

prompts: Works such as The Black Book of Communism and Bloodlands legitimized debates on the
baseline: Works such as The Black Book of Communism and Bloodlands legitimized debates on the comparison of Nazism and Stalinism, and by extension communism, and the former work in particular was important in the criminalization of communism.

prompts: According to Freedom House , Communism is " considered one of the
baseline: According to Freedom House, Communism is "considered one of the two great totalitarian movements of the 20th century", the other being Nazism, but added that "there is an important difference in how the world has treated these two execrable phenomena.":

prompts: The failure of Communist governments to live up to the
baseline: The failure of Communist governments to live up to the ideal of a communist society, their general trend towards increasing authoritarianism, their bureaucracy, and the inherent inefficiencies in their economies have been linked to the decline of communism in the late 20th century.

prompts: By contrast , the Central European states of the former Eastern Bloc – Czech Republic , Hungary , Poland , and Slovakia – showed healthy increases in
baseline: By contrast, the Central European states of the former Eastern Bloc–Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, and Slovakia–showed healthy increases in life expectancy from the 1990s onward, compared to nearly thirty years of stagnation under Communism.

prompts: The economies of Eastern Bloc countries had previously experienced stagnation in the
baseline: The economies of Eastern Bloc countries had previously experienced stagnation in the 1980s under Communism.

prompts: A common expression throughout Eastern Europe after 1989 was " everything they told us about communism
baseline: A common expression throughout Eastern Europe after 1989 was "everything they told us about communism was a lie, but everything they told us about capitalism was true.": 192  The right-libertarian think tank Cato Institute has stated that the analyses done of post-communist countries in the 1990s were "premature" and "that early and rapid reformers by far outperformed gradual reformers" on GDP per capita, the United Nations Human Development Index and political freedom, in addition to developing better institutions.

prompts: However , Branko Milanović wrote in 2015 that following the end of
baseline: However, Branko Milanović wrote in 2015 that following the end of the Cold War, many of those countries' economies declined to such an extent during the transition to capitalism that they have yet to return to the point they were prior to the collapse of communism.

prompts: Several scholars state that the negative economic developments in post - Communist countries after the fall of Communism led to increased nationalist
baseline: Several scholars state that the negative economic developments in post-Communist countries after the fall of Communism led to increased nationalist sentiment and nostalgia for the Communist era.

prompts: In addition , 61 percent said that standards of living were now higher than they had been under Communism , while only 31 percent said that they were
baseline: In addition, 61 percent said that standards of living were now higher than they had been under Communism, while only 31 percent said that they were worse, with the remaining 8 percent saying that they did not know or that standards of living had not changed.

prompts: According to Grigore Pop - Eleches and Joshua Tucker in their book Communism 's Shadow : Historical Legacies and Contemporary Political Attitudes , citizens of post - Communist countries are less supportive of
baseline: According to Grigore Pop-Eleches and Joshua Tucker in their book Communism's Shadow: Historical Legacies and Contemporary Political Attitudes, citizens of post-Communist countries are less supportive of democracy and more supportive of government-provided social welfare.

prompts: Those who are left - authoritarian in this sense more often tend to be older
baseline: Those who are left-authoritarian in this sense more often tend to be older generations that lived under Communism.

prompts: Dean argues that , when people think of capitalism ,
baseline: Dean argues that, when people think of capitalism, they do not consider what are its worst results (climate change, economic inequality, hyperinflation, the Great Depression, the Great Recession, the robber barons, and unemployment) because the history of capitalism is viewed as dynamic and nuanced; the history of communism is not considered dynamic or nuanced, and there is a fixed historical narrative of communism that emphasizes authoritarianism, the gulag, starvation, and violence.

prompts: Ghodsee , along with the historians Gary Gerstle and Walter Scheidel , suggest that the rise
baseline: Ghodsee, along with the historians Gary Gerstle and Walter Scheidel, suggest that the rise and fall of communism had a significant impact on the development and decline of labor movements and social welfare states in the United States and other Western societies.

prompts: Gerstle argues that organized labor in the United States was strongest when the threat of communism reached its peak ,
baseline: Gerstle argues that organized labor in the United States was strongest when the threat of communism reached its peak, and the decline of both organized labor and the welfare state coincided with the collapse of communism.

prompts: Communism ( from Latin communis , ' common , universal ' ) is a sociopolitical , philosophical , and economic ideology within the socialist movement , whose goal is the creation of a communist society , a socioeconomic order centered around common ownership
baseline: Communism (from Latin communis, 'common, universal') is a sociopolitical, philosophical, and economic ideology within the socialist movement, whose goal is the creation of a communist society, a socioeconomic order centered around common ownership of the means of production, distribution, and exchange that allocates products to everyone in the society based on need.

prompts: A communist society would entail the absence of
baseline: A communist society would entail the absence of private property and social classes, and ultimately money and the state (or nation state).

prompts: This reflects a distinction between a more libertarian socialist approach of communization , revolutionary spontaneity , and workers ' self - management , and a more authoritarian vanguardist or communist party - driven approach through the
baseline: This reflects a distinction between a more libertarian socialist approach of communization, revolutionary spontaneity, and workers' self-management, and a more authoritarian vanguardist or communist party-driven approach through the development of a socialist state, followed by the withering away of the state.

prompts: As one of the main ideologies on the political spectrum , communism is placed on the left
baseline: As one of the main ideologies on the political spectrum, communism is placed on the left-wing alongside socialism, and communist parties and movements have been described as radical left or far-left.

prompts: According to this analysis , a communist revolution would put the working class
baseline: According to this analysis, a communist revolution would put the working class in power, and in turn establish common ownership of property, the primary element in the transformation of society towards a communist mode of production.

prompts: In the 20th century , several ostensibly Communist governments espousing Marxism – Leninism
baseline: In the 20th century, several ostensibly Communist governments espousing Marxism–Leninism and its variants came into power, first in the Soviet Union with the Russian Revolution of 1917, and then in portions of Eastern Europe, Asia, and a few other regions after World War II.

prompts: During most of the 20th century , around one - third of the world 's population lived under Communist governments
baseline: During most of the 20th century, around one-third of the world's population lived under Communist governments.

prompts: These governments were characterized by one -
baseline: These governments were characterized by one-party rule by a communist party, the rejection of private property and capitalism, state control of economic activity and mass media, restrictions on freedom of religion, and suppression of opposition and dissent.

prompts: With the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991 , several previously Communist governments repudiated or abolished Communist
baseline: With the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, several previously Communist governments repudiated or abolished Communist rule altogether.

prompts: Afterwards , only a small number of nominally Communist governments remained , such as
baseline: Afterwards, only a small number of nominally Communist governments remained, such as China, Cuba, Laos, North Korea, and Vietnam.

prompts: The decline of communism in the late 20th century has been attributed to the inherent
baseline: The decline of communism in the late 20th century has been attributed to the inherent inefficiencies of communist economies and the general trend of communist governments towards authoritarianism and bureaucracy.

prompts: While the emergence of the Soviet Union as the world 's first nominally Communist state led to communism 's
baseline: While the emergence of the Soviet Union as the world's first nominally Communist state led to communism's widespread association with the Soviet economic model, several scholars posit that in practice the model functioned as a form of state capitalism.

prompts: Public memory of 20th - century Communist states has been described as a battleground
baseline: Public memory of 20th-century Communist states has been described as a battleground between anti anti-communism and anti-communism.

prompts: Many authors have written about mass killings under communist regimes and mortality rates , such as excess mortality in the Soviet Union under Joseph Stalin , which remain controversial , polarized
baseline: Many authors have written about mass killings under communist regimes and mortality rates, such as excess mortality in the Soviet Union under Joseph Stalin, which remain controversial, polarized, and debated topics in academia, historiography, and politics when discussing communism and the legacy of Communist states.

prompts: Communism came to be primarily associated with Marxism , most specifically embodied in The Communist
baseline: Communism came to be primarily associated with Marxism, most specifically embodied in The Communist Manifesto, which proposed a particular type of communism.

prompts: One of the first uses of the word in its modern sense is in a letter
baseline: One of the first uses of the word in its modern sense is in a letter sent by Victor d'Hupay to Nicolas Restif de la Bretonne around 1785, in which d'Hupay describes himself as an auteur communiste ("communist author").

prompts: The hammer and sickle is a common theme
baseline: The hammer and sickle is a common theme of communist symbolism.

prompts: Friedrich Engels stated that in 1848 , at the time when The Communist Manifesto was first published , socialism was
baseline: Friedrich Engels stated that in 1848, at the time when The Communist Manifesto was first published, socialism was respectable on the continent, while communism was not; the Owenites in England and the Fourierists in France were considered respectable socialists, while working-class movements that "proclaimed the necessity of total social change" denoted themselves communists.

prompts: This latter branch of socialism produced the communist work
baseline: This latter branch of socialism produced the communist work of Étienne Cabet in France and Wilhelm Weitling in Germany.

prompts: A distinction between communist and socialist as descriptors of political ideologies arose in 1918 after
baseline: A distinction between communist and socialist as descriptors of political ideologies arose in 1918 after the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party renamed itself as the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, which resulted in the adjective Communist being used to refer to socialists who supported the politics and theories of Bolshevism, Leninism, and later in the 1920s those of Marxism–Leninism.

prompts: In spite of this common usage , Communist parties also continued to describe themselves
baseline: In spite of this common usage, Communist parties also continued to describe themselves as socialists dedicated to socialism.

prompts: In the United States , communism is widely used as a pejorative
baseline: In the United States, communism is widely used as a pejorative term as part of a Red Scare, much like socialism, and mainly in reference to authoritarian socialism and Communist states.

prompts: The emergence of the Soviet Union as the world 's first nominally Communist state led to the term
baseline: The emergence of the Soviet Union as the world's first nominally Communist state led to the term's widespread association with Marxism–Leninism and the Soviet-type economic planning model.

prompts: In his essay " Judging Nazism and Communism " , Martin Malia defines a " generic
baseline: In his essay "Judging Nazism and Communism", Martin Malia defines a "generic Communism" category as any Communist political party movement led by intellectuals; this umbrella term allows grouping together such different regimes as radical Soviet industrialism and the Khmer Rouge's anti-urbanism.

prompts: While the term Communist state is used by Western historians
baseline: While the term Communist state is used by Western historians, political scientists, and news media to refer to countries ruled by Communist parties, these socialist states themselves did not describe themselves as communist or claim to have achieved communism; they referred to themselves as being a socialist state that is in the process of constructing communism.

prompts: Terms used by Communist states include national - democratic , people 's democratic , socialist - oriented , and workers
baseline: Terms used by Communist states include national-democratic, people's democratic, socialist-oriented, and workers and peasants' states.

prompts: Plato , in particular , has been considered as a possible
baseline: Plato, in particular, has been considered as a possible communist or socialist theorist, or as the first author to give communism a serious consideration.

prompts: At one time or another , various small communist communities existed , generally under
baseline: At one time or another, various small communist communities existed, generally under the inspiration of religious text.

prompts: As an economic system , communism was attractive to many
baseline: As an economic system, communism was attractive to many of the peasants who supported social revolution in sixteenth century central Europe." This link was highlighted in one of Karl Marx's early writings; Marx stated that "s Christ is the intermediary unto whom man unburdens all his divinity, all his religious bonds, so the state is the mediator unto which he transfers all his Godlessness, all his human liberty." Thomas Müntzer led a large Anabaptist communist movement during the German Peasants' War, which Friedrich Engels analyzed in his 1850 work The Peasant War in Germany.

prompts: The Marxist communist ethos that aims for unity reflects the Christian universalist
baseline: The Marxist communist ethos that aims for unity reflects the Christian universalist teaching that humankind is one and that there is only one god who does not discriminate among people.

prompts: Communist thought has also been traced back to the
baseline: Communist thought has also been traced back to the works of the 16th-century English writer Thomas More.

prompts: Marxist communist theoretician Karl Kautsky , who popularized Marxist communism in
baseline: Marxist communist theoretician Karl Kautsky, who popularized Marxist communism in Western Europe more than any other thinker apart from Engels, published Thomas More and His Utopia, a work about More, whose ideas could be regarded as "the foregleam of Modern Socialism" according to Kautsky.

prompts: In the 17th century , communist thought surfaced again in England
baseline: In the 17th century, communist thought surfaced again in England, where a Puritan religious group known as the Diggers advocated the abolition of private ownership of land.

prompts: Unlike many previous communist communities , they replaced the religious emphasis
baseline: Unlike many previous communist communities, they replaced the religious emphasis with a rational and philanthropic basis.

prompts: In 1848 , Marx and Engels offered a new definition
baseline: In 1848, Marx and Engels offered a new definition of communism and popularized the term in their famous pamphlet The Communist Manifesto.

prompts: In 1917 , the October Revolution in Russia set the conditions for
baseline: In 1917, the October Revolution in Russia set the conditions for the rise to state power of Vladimir Lenin's Bolsheviks, which was the first time any avowedly communist party reached that position.

prompts: Some left - wing parties , such as the Socialist Party of Great Britain , boasted of having called
baseline: Some left-wing parties, such as the Socialist Party of Great Britain, boasted of having called the Bolsheviks, and by extension those Communist states which either followed or were inspired by the Soviet Bolshevik model of development, establishing state capitalism in late 1917, as would be described during the 20th century by several academics, economists, and other scholars, or a command economy.

prompts: While Joseph Stalin stated that the law of value would still apply to socialism and
baseline: While Joseph Stalin stated that the law of value would still apply to socialism and that the Soviet Union was socialist under this new definition, which was followed by other Communist leaders, many other communists maintain the original definition and state that Communist states never established socialism in this sense.

prompts: Before the broad ban in 1921 , there were several factions in
baseline: Before the broad ban in 1921, there were several factions in the Communist party, more prominently among them the Left Opposition, the Right Opposition, and the Workers' Opposition, which debated on the path of development to follow.

prompts: Trotskyism overtook the left communists as the main dissident communist current , while more libertarian communisms , dating back to the
baseline: Trotskyism overtook the left communists as the main dissident communist current, while more libertarian communisms, dating back to the libertarian Marxist current of council communism, remained important dissident communisms outside the Soviet Union.

prompts: The Great Purge of 1936–1938 was Joseph Stalin 's attempt to destroy any possible opposition
baseline: The Great Purge of 1936–1938 was Joseph Stalin's attempt to destroy any possible opposition within the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.

prompts: For most Westerners and anti - communist Russians , Stalin is viewed overwhelmingly negatively as
baseline: For most Westerners and anti-communist Russians, Stalin is viewed overwhelmingly negatively as a mass murderer; for significant numbers of Russians and Georgians, he is regarded as a great statesman and state-builder.

prompts: After the Chinese Civil War , Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Party came to power in
baseline: After the Chinese Civil War, Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Party came to power in 1949 as the Nationalist government headed by the Kuomintang fled to the island of Taiwan.

prompts: After Stalin 's death in 1953 , relations with Moscow soured   – Mao
baseline: After Stalin's death in 1953, relations with Moscow soured – Mao thought Stalin's successors had betrayed the Communist ideal.

prompts: Both began forging alliances with communist supporters around the globe , thereby splitting the worldwide movement
baseline: Both began forging alliances with communist supporters around the globe, thereby splitting the worldwide movement into two hostile camps.

prompts: Mao 's goal was to purify communism by removing pro - capitalists
baseline: Mao's goal was to purify communism by removing pro-capitalists and traditionalists by imposing Maoist orthodoxy within the Chinese Communist Party.

prompts: The movement spread into the military
baseline: The movement spread into the military, urban workers, and the Communist party leadership itself.

prompts: States that had communist governments in red , states that the Soviet
baseline: States that had communist governments in red, states that the Soviet Union believed at one point to be moving toward socialism in orange, and states with constitutional references to socialism in yellow

prompts: The Communist Party of China , led by Mao Zedong
baseline: The Communist Party of China, led by Mao Zedong, established the People's Republic of China, which would follow its own ideological path of development following the Sino-Soviet split.

prompts: In Western Europe , communist parties were part of several
baseline: In Western Europe, communist parties were part of several post-war governments, and even when the Cold War forced many of those countries to remove them from government, such as in Italy, they remained part of the liberal-democratic process.

prompts: By the 1960s and 1970s , many Western communist parties had criticized many of the
baseline: By the 1960s and 1970s, many Western communist parties had criticized many of the actions of communist states, distanced from them, and developed a democratic road to socialism, which became known as Eurocommunism.

prompts: In 1959 , Cuban communist revolutionaries overthrew Cuba 's previous
baseline: In 1959, Cuban communist revolutionaries overthrew Cuba's previous government under the dictator Fulgencio Batista.

prompts: Communist flag at night at
baseline: Communist flag at night at Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, year 2024

prompts: A poster of the Communist
baseline: A poster of the Communist Party of Vietnam in Hanoi

prompts: Communist parties , or their descendant parties , remain politically important in
baseline: Communist parties, or their descendant parties, remain politically important in several other countries.

prompts: With the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the Fall of Communism , there was a split between
baseline: With the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the Fall of Communism, there was a split between those hardline Communists, sometimes referred to in the media as neo-Stalinists, who remained committed to orthodox Marxism–Leninism, and those, such as The Left in Germany, who work within the liberal-democratic process for a democratic road to socialism; other ruling Communist parties became closer to democratic socialist and social-democratic parties.

prompts: Outside Communist states , reformed Communist parties have led or been part
baseline: Outside Communist states, reformed Communist parties have led or been part of left-leaning government or regional coalitions, including in the former Eastern Bloc.

prompts: The Communist Party of the Russian Federation has some supporters ,
baseline: The Communist Party of the Russian Federation has some supporters, but is reformist rather than revolutionary, aiming to lessen the inequalities of Russia's market economy.

prompts: North Korea , the last Communist country that still practices Soviet - style
baseline: North Korea, the last Communist country that still practices Soviet-style Communism, is both repressive and isolationist.

prompts: Communist political thought and theory are diverse but share several core elements
baseline: Communist political thought and theory are diverse but share several core elements.

prompts: As the productive forces continued to advance , the communist
baseline: As the productive forces continued to advance, the communist society, i.e. a classless, stateless, humane society based on common ownership, follows the maxim "From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs."

prompts: The communist mode of production would succeed capitalism as humanity
baseline: The communist mode of production would succeed capitalism as humanity's new mode of production through workers' revolution.

prompts: Leninist revolutionary leadership is based upon The Communist Manifesto ( 1848 ) , identifying the Communist party
baseline: Leninist revolutionary leadership is based upon The Communist Manifesto (1848), identifying the Communist party as "the most advanced and resolute section of the working class parties of every country; that section which pushes forward all others." As the vanguard party, the Bolsheviks viewed history through the theoretical framework of dialectical materialism, which sanctioned political commitment to the successful overthrow of capitalism, and then to instituting socialism; and as the revolutionary national government, to realize the socio-economic transition by all means.

prompts: It describes the specific political ideology which Stalin implemented in the Communist
baseline: It describes the specific political ideology which Stalin implemented in the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and in a global scale in the Comintern.

prompts: Marxism – Leninism was the official ideology of 20th - century Communist parties ( including Trotskyist ) , and was developed after the death
baseline: Marxism–Leninism was the official ideology of 20th-century Communist parties (including Trotskyist), and was developed after the death of Lenin; its three principles were dialectical materialism, the leading role of the Communist party through democratic centralism, and a planned economy with industrialization and agricultural collectivization.

prompts: Marxism – Leninism is misleading because Marx and Lenin never sanctioned or supported the
baseline: Marxism–Leninism is misleading because Marx and Lenin never sanctioned or supported the creation of an -ism after them, and is revealing because, being popularized after Lenin's death by Stalin, it contained those three doctrinal and institutionalized principles that became a model for later Soviet-type regimes; its global influence, having at its height covered at least one-third of the world's population, has made Marxist–Leninist a convenient label for the Communist bloc as a dynamic ideological order.

prompts: During the Cold War , Marxism – Leninism was the ideology of
baseline: During the Cold War, Marxism–Leninism was the ideology of the most clearly visible communist movement and is the most prominent ideology associated with communism.

prompts: Social fascism was a theory supported by the Comintern and affiliated Communist parties during the early 1930s , which held that social democracy
baseline: Social fascism was a theory supported by the Comintern and affiliated Communist parties during the early 1930s, which held that social democracy was a variant of fascism because it stood in the way of a dictatorship of the proletariat, in addition to a shared corporatist economic model.

prompts: The social fascism theory was advocated vociferously by the Communist Party of Germany , which was largely controlled and funded by
baseline: The social fascism theory was advocated vociferously by the Communist Party of Germany, which was largely controlled and funded by the Soviet leadership from 1928.

prompts: Where Khrushchev pursued an interpretation that differed from Stalin ,
baseline: Where Khrushchev pursued an interpretation that differed from Stalin, the anti-revisionists within the international communist movement remained dedicated to Stalin's ideological legacy and criticized the Soviet Union under Khrushchev and his successors as state capitalist and social imperialist due to its hopes of achieving peace with the United States.

prompts: Until the death of Joseph Stalin in 1953 , the Soviet Communist party referred to its own
baseline: Until the death of Joseph Stalin in 1953, the Soviet Communist party referred to its own ideology as Marxism–Leninism–Stalinism.

prompts: Marxism – Leninism has been criticized by other communist and Marxist tendencies , which state that Marxist – Leninist states did not establish socialism but rather
baseline: Marxism–Leninism has been criticized by other communist and Marxist tendencies, which state that Marxist–Leninist states did not establish socialism but rather state capitalism.

prompts: Whether the proletariat was actually in control of the Marxist – Leninist states is a matter of
baseline: Whether the proletariat was actually in control of the Marxist–Leninist states is a matter of debate between Marxism–Leninism and other communist tendencies.

prompts: To these tendencies , Marxism – Leninism is neither Marxism nor
baseline: To these tendencies, Marxism–Leninism is neither Marxism nor Leninism nor the union of both but rather an artificial term created to justify Stalin's ideological distortion, forced into the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and the Comintern.

prompts: It supported another communist revolution
baseline: It supported another communist revolution in the Soviet Union and proletarian internationalism.

prompts: Developed from the 1950s until the Deng Xiaoping Chinese economic reform in the 1970s , it was widely applied as the guiding
baseline: Developed from the 1950s until the Deng Xiaoping Chinese economic reform in the 1970s, it was widely applied as the guiding political and military ideology of the Communist Party of China and as the theory guiding revolutionary movements around the world.

prompts: Eurocommunism was a revisionist trend in the 1970s and 1980s within various Western European communist parties , claiming to develop a
baseline: Eurocommunism was a revisionist trend in the 1970s and 1980s within various Western European communist parties, claiming to develop a theory and practice of social transformation more relevant to their region.

prompts: Especially prominent within the French Communist Party , Italian Communist Party , and Communist Party of Spain , Communists of this nature sought to undermine the
baseline: Especially prominent within the French Communist Party, Italian Communist Party, and Communist Party of Spain, Communists of this nature sought to undermine the influence of the Soviet Union and its All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks) during the Cold War.

prompts: Enrico Berlinguer , general secretary of Italy 's major Communist party , was widely considered the father of
baseline: Enrico Berlinguer, general secretary of Italy's major Communist party, was widely considered the father of Eurocommunism.

prompts: Council communism is a movement that originated from Germany and
baseline: Council communism is a movement that originated from Germany and the Netherlands in the 1920s, whose primary organization was the Communist Workers Party of Germany.

prompts: This view is opposed to both the reformist and the Leninist communist ideologies , which respectively stress parliamentary and institutional
baseline: This view is opposed to both the reformist and the Leninist communist ideologies, which respectively stress parliamentary and institutional government by applying social reforms on the one hand, and vanguard parties and participative democratic centralism on the other.

prompts: Left communism is the range of communist viewpoints held by the communist
baseline: Left communism is the range of communist viewpoints held by the communist left, which criticizes the political ideas and practices espoused, particularly following the series of revolutions that brought World War I to an end by Bolsheviks and social democrats.

prompts: Left communists assert positions which they regard as more authentically
baseline: Left communists assert positions which they regard as more authentically Marxist and proletarian than the views of Marxism–Leninism espoused by the Communist International after its first congress (March 1919) and during its second congress (July–August 1920).

prompts: Bordigism is a Leninist left - communist current named after Amadeo Bordiga
baseline: Bordigism is a Leninist left-communist current named after Amadeo Bordiga, who has been described as being "more Leninist than Lenin", and considered himself to be a Leninist.

prompts: Peter Kropotkin , the main theorist of anarcho - communism , stated that a revolutionary
baseline: Peter Kropotkin, the main theorist of anarcho-communism, stated that a revolutionary society should "transform itself immediately into a communist society", that it should go immediately into what Marx had regarded as the "more advanced, completed, phase of communism".

prompts: Although there is no universal agreement on the exact dates when communistic ideas and practices in Christianity began , many Christian
baseline: Although there is no universal agreement on the exact dates when communistic ideas and practices in Christianity began, many Christian communists state that evidence from the Bible suggests that the first Christians, including the Apostles in the New Testament, established their own small communist society in the years following Jesus' death and resurrection.

prompts: Russian musician Yegor Letov was an outspoken Christian communist , and in a 1995 interview he was quoted as saying :
baseline: Russian musician Yegor Letov was an outspoken Christian communist, and in a 1995 interview he was quoted as saying: "Communism is the Kingdom of God on Earth."

prompts: Morris also wrote that Soviet - style communism " did not ' work ' " due
baseline: Morris also wrote that Soviet-style communism "did not 'work'" due to "an over-centralised, oppressive, bureaucratic and rigid economic and political system." Historian Andrzej Paczkowski summarized communism as "an ideology that seemed clearly the opposite, that was based on the secular desire of humanity to achieve equality and social justice, and that promised a great leap forward into freedom." In contrast, Austrian-American economist Ludwig von Mises argued that by abolishing free markets, communist officials would not have the price system necessary to guide their planned production.

prompts: Anti - communism developed as soon as communism became a conscious political
baseline: Anti-communism developed as soon as communism became a conscious political movement in the 19th century, and anti-communist mass killings have been reported against alleged communists, or their alleged supporters, which were committed by anti-communists and political organizations or governments opposed to communism.

prompts: The communist movement has faced opposition since it was founded and the opposition
baseline: The communist movement has faced opposition since it was founded and the opposition to it has often been organized and violent.

prompts: Many of these anti - communist mass killing campaigns , primarily during the Cold War , were supported by the United
baseline: Many of these anti-communist mass killing campaigns, primarily during the Cold War, were supported by the United States and its Western Bloc allies, including those who were formally part of the Non-Aligned Movement, such as the Indonesian mass killings of 1965–66 and Operation Condor in South America.

prompts: Many authors have written about excess deaths
baseline: Many authors have written about excess deaths under Communist states and mortality rates, such as excess mortality in the Soviet Union under Joseph Stalin.

prompts: Some authors posit that there is a Communist death toll , whose death estimates vary widely , depending
baseline: Some authors posit that there is a Communist death toll, whose death estimates vary widely, depending on the definitions of the deaths that are included in them, ranging from lows of 10–20 million to highs over 100 million.

prompts: Higher estimates account for actions that Communist governments committed against civilians ,
baseline: Higher estimates account for actions that Communist governments committed against civilians, including executions, human-made famines, and deaths that occurred during, or resulted from, imprisonment, and forced deportations and labor.

prompts: What matters is that many , many people were killed by communist regimes
baseline: What matters is that many, many people were killed by communist regimes." Historian Mark Bradley wrote that while the exact numbers have been in dispute, the order of magnitude is not.

prompts: These scholars state that most Communist states did not engage in mass killings
baseline: These scholars state that most Communist states did not engage in mass killings; Benjamin Valentino proposes the category of Communist mass killing, alongside colonial, counter-guerrilla, and ethnic mass killing, as a subtype of dispossessive mass killing to distinguish it from coercive mass killing.

prompts: Daniel Goldhagen argues that 20th century communist regimes " have killed more people than
baseline: Daniel Goldhagen argues that 20th century communist regimes "have killed more people than any other regime type."

prompts: Many commentators on the political right point to the mass deaths under Communist states , claiming them as an
baseline: Many commentators on the political right point to the mass deaths under Communist states, claiming them as an indictment of communism.

prompts: According to Dovid Katz and other historians , a historical revisionist view of the double genocide theory , equating mass deaths under
baseline: According to Dovid Katz and other historians, a historical revisionist view of the double genocide theory, equating mass deaths under Communist states with the Holocaust, is popular in Eastern European countries and the Baltic states, and their approaches of history have been incorporated in the European Union agenda, among them the Prague Declaration in June 2008 and the European Day of Remembrance for Victims of Stalinism and Nazism, which was proclaimed by the European Parliament in August 2008 and endorsed by the OSCE in Europe in July 2009.

prompts: Criticism of communism can be divided into two broad categories , namely that criticism of Communist party rule that concerns with the practical aspects of 20th - century Communist states , and criticism of Marxism and communism generally that concerns its principles and
baseline: Criticism of communism can be divided into two broad categories, namely that criticism of Communist party rule that concerns with the practical aspects of 20th-century Communist states, and criticism of Marxism and communism generally that concerns its principles and theory.

prompts: Public memory of 20th - century Communist states has been described as a battleground
baseline: Public memory of 20th-century Communist states has been described as a battleground between the communist-sympathetic or anti-anti-communist political left and the anti-communism of the political right.

prompts: Defenders of communism on the political left say that the deaths
baseline: Defenders of communism on the political left say that the deaths were caused by specific authoritarian regimes and not communism as an ideology, while also pointing to anti-communist mass killings and deaths in wars that they argue were caused by capitalism and anti-communism as a counterpoint to the deaths under Communist states.

prompts: According to Hungarian sociologist and politician András Bozóki , positive aspects of communist countries included support for social
baseline: According to Hungarian sociologist and politician András Bozóki, positive aspects of communist countries included support for social mobility and equality, the elimination of illiteracy, urbanization, more accessible healthcare and housing, regional mobility with public transportation, the elimination of semi-feudal hierarchies, more women entering the labor market, and free access to higher education.

prompts: Negative aspects of communist countries , on the other hand according to Bozóki included
baseline: Negative aspects of communist countries, on the other hand according to Bozóki included the suppression of freedom, the loss of trust in civil society; a culture of fear and corruption; reduced international travel; dependency on the party and state; Central Europe becoming a satellite of the Soviet Union; the creation of closed societies, leading to xenophobia, racism, prejudice, cynicism and pessimism; women only being emancipated in the workforce; the oppression of national identity; and relativist ethical societal standards.

prompts: The narrative posits that famines and mass deaths by Communist states can be attributed to a single
baseline: The narrative posits that famines and mass deaths by Communist states can be attributed to a single cause and that communism, as "the deadliest ideology in history", or in the words of Jonathan Rauch as "the deadliest fantasy in human history", represents the greatest threat to humanity.

prompts: The failure of Communist governments to live up to the
baseline: The failure of Communist governments to live up to the ideal of a communist society, their general trend towards increasing authoritarianism, their bureaucracy, and the inherent inefficiencies in their economies have been linked to the decline of communism in the late 20th century.

prompts: Walter Scheidel stated that despite wide - reaching government actions ,
baseline: Walter Scheidel stated that despite wide-reaching government actions, Communist states failed to achieve long-term economic, social, and political success.

prompts: The experience of the dissolution of the Soviet Union , the North Korean famine , and alleged economic underperformance when
baseline: The experience of the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the North Korean famine, and alleged economic underperformance when compared to developed free market systems are cited as examples of Communist states failing to build a successful state while relying entirely on what they view as orthodox Marxism.

prompts: Despite those shortcomings , Philipp Ther stated that there was
baseline: Despite those shortcomings, Philipp Ther stated that there was a general increase in the standard of living throughout Eastern Bloc countries as the result of modernization programs under Communist governments.

prompts: Most experts agree there was a   significant increase in mortality rates following the years 1989
baseline: Most experts agree there was a significant increase in mortality rates following the years 1989 and 1991, including a 2014 World Health Organization report which concluded that the "health of people in the former Soviet countries deteriorated dramatically after the collapse of the Soviet Union." Post-Communist Russia during the IMF-backed economic reforms of Boris Yeltsin experienced surging economic inequality and poverty as unemployment reached double digits by the early to mid 1990s.

prompts: A common expression throughout Eastern Europe after 1989 was " everything they told us about communism
baseline: A common expression throughout Eastern Europe after 1989 was "everything they told us about communism was a lie, but everything they told us about capitalism was true.": 192  The right-libertarian think tank Cato Institute has stated that the analyses done of post-communist countries in the 1990s were "premature" and "that early and rapid reformers by far outperformed gradual reformers" on GDP per capita, the United Nations Human Development Index and political freedom, in addition to developing better institutions.

prompts: The average post - Communist country had returned to 1989 levels
baseline: The average post-Communist country had returned to 1989 levels of per-capita GDP by 2005.

prompts: Several scholars state that the negative economic developments in post - Communist countries after the fall of Communism led to increased nationalist
baseline: Several scholars state that the negative economic developments in post-Communist countries after the fall of Communism led to increased nationalist sentiment and nostalgia for the Communist era.

prompts: According to Grigore Pop - Eleches and Joshua Tucker in their book Communism 's Shadow : Historical Legacies and Contemporary Political Attitudes , citizens of post - Communist countries are less supportive of
baseline: According to Grigore Pop-Eleches and Joshua Tucker in their book Communism's Shadow: Historical Legacies and Contemporary Political Attitudes, citizens of post-Communist countries are less supportive of democracy and more supportive of government-provided social welfare.

prompts: They also found that those who lived under Communist rule
baseline: They also found that those who lived under Communist rule were more likely to be left-authoritarian (referencing the right-wing authoritarian personality) than citizens of other countries.

prompts: In contrast , younger post - Communist generations continue to be anti
baseline: In contrast, younger post-Communist generations continue to be anti-democratic but are not as left-wing ideologically, which in the words of Pop-Eleches and Tucker "might help explain the growing popularity of right-wing populists in the region."

prompts: Conservatives , liberals , and social democrats generally view 20th - century
baseline: Conservatives, liberals, and social democrats generally view 20th-century Communist states as unqualified failures.

prompts: Both Gerstle and Scheidel posit that as economic elites in the West became more fearful of
baseline: Both Gerstle and Scheidel posit that as economic elites in the West became more fearful of possible communist revolutions in their own societies, especially as the tyranny and violence associated with communist governments became more apparent, the more willing they were to compromise with the working class, and much less so once the threat waned.

prompts: As one of the main ideologies on the political spectrum , communism is placed on the left
baseline: As one of the main ideologies on the political spectrum, communism is placed on the left-wing alongside socialism, and communist parties and movements have been described as radical left or far-left.

prompts: As one of the many types of socialism , communism became the dominant political
baseline: As one of the many types of socialism, communism became the dominant political tendency, along with social democracy, within the international socialist movement by the early 1920s.

prompts: The modern definition and usage of the term socialism was settled by the 1860s
baseline: The modern definition and usage of the term socialism was settled by the 1860s, becoming predominant over alternative terms such as associationism (Fourierism), mutualism, or co-operative, which had previously been used as synonyms.

prompts: An early distinction between communism and socialism was that the latter
baseline: An early distinction between communism and socialism was that the latter aimed to only socialize production, whereas the former aimed to socialize both production and consumption (in the form of common access to final goods).

prompts: Socialism has been described as a philosophy seeking distributive justice ,
baseline: Socialism has been described as a philosophy seeking distributive justice, and communism as a subset of socialism that prefers economic equality as its form of distributive justice.

prompts: In 19th century Europe , the use of the terms communism and socialism eventually accorded with the cultural
baseline: In 19th century Europe, the use of the terms communism and socialism eventually accorded with the cultural attitude of adherents and opponents towards religion.

prompts: Friedrich Engels stated that in 1848 , at the time when The Communist Manifesto was first published , socialism was
baseline: Friedrich Engels stated that in 1848, at the time when The Communist Manifesto was first published, socialism was respectable on the continent, while communism was not; the Owenites in England and the Fourierists in France were considered respectable socialists, while working-class movements that "proclaimed the necessity of total social change" denoted themselves communists.

prompts: This latter branch of socialism produced the communist work
baseline: This latter branch of socialism produced the communist work of Étienne Cabet in France and Wilhelm Weitling in Germany.

prompts: By 1888 , Marxists employed the term socialism in place of communism , which had come to be considered
baseline: By 1888, Marxists employed the term socialism in place of communism, which had come to be considered an old-fashioned synonym for the former.

prompts: It was not until 1917 , with the October Revolution , that socialism came to be used
baseline: It was not until 1917, with the October Revolution, that socialism came to be used to refer to a distinct stage between capitalism and communism.

prompts: In spite of this common usage , Communist parties also continued to describe themselves
baseline: In spite of this common usage, Communist parties also continued to describe themselves as socialists dedicated to socialism.

prompts: According to The Oxford Handbook of Karl Marx , " Marx used many terms to
baseline: According to The Oxford Handbook of Karl Marx, "Marx used many terms to refer to a post-capitalist society – positive humanism, socialism, Communism, realm of free individuality, free association of producers, etc.

prompts: The notion that ' socialism ' and ' Communism ' are distinct historical stages is alien to his
baseline: The notion that 'socialism' and 'Communism' are distinct historical stages is alien to his work and only entered the lexicon of Marxism after his death." According to the Encyclopædia Britannica, "Exactly how communism differs from socialism has long been a matter of debate, but the distinction rests largely on the communists' adherence to the revolutionary socialism of Karl Marx."

prompts: In the United States , communism is widely used as a pejorative
baseline: In the United States, communism is widely used as a pejorative term as part of a Red Scare, much like socialism, and mainly in reference to authoritarian socialism and Communist states.

prompts: Marxist communist theoretician Karl Kautsky , who popularized Marxist communism in
baseline: Marxist communist theoretician Karl Kautsky, who popularized Marxist communism in Western Europe more than any other thinker apart from Engels, published Thomas More and His Utopia, a work about More, whose ideas could be regarded as "the foregleam of Modern Socialism" according to Kautsky.

prompts: The event generated a great deal of practical and theoretical debate within the Marxist movement , as Marx stated that socialism and
baseline: The event generated a great deal of practical and theoretical debate within the Marxist movement, as Marx stated that socialism and communism would be built upon foundations laid by the most advanced capitalist development; however, the Russian Empire was one of the poorest countries in Europe with an enormous, largely illiterate peasantry, and a minority of industrial workers.

prompts: Other communists and Marxists , especially social democrats who favored the development of
baseline: Other communists and Marxists, especially social democrats who favored the development of liberal democracy as a prerequisite to socialism, were critical of the Bolsheviks from the beginning due to Russia being seen as too backward for a socialist revolution.

prompts: Before the Soviet path of development became known as socialism ,
baseline: Before the Soviet path of development became known as socialism, in reference to the two-stage theory, communists made no major distinction between the socialist mode of production and communism; it is consistent with, and helped to inform, early concepts of socialism in which the law of value no longer directs economic activity.

prompts: Monetary relations in the form of exchange - value , profit , interest , and wage labor would not operate and apply to
baseline: Monetary relations in the form of exchange-value, profit, interest, and wage labor would not operate and apply to Marxist socialism.

prompts: While Joseph Stalin stated that the law of value would still apply to socialism and
baseline: While Joseph Stalin stated that the law of value would still apply to socialism and that the Soviet Union was socialist under this new definition, which was followed by other Communist leaders, many other communists maintain the original definition and state that Communist states never established socialism in this sense.

prompts: Lenin described his policies as state capitalism but saw them as necessary
baseline: Lenin described his policies as state capitalism but saw them as necessary for the development of socialism, which left-wing critics say was never established, while some Marxist–Leninists state that it was established only during the Stalin era and Mao era, and then became capitalist states ruled by revisionists; others state that Maoist China was always state capitalist, and uphold People's Socialist Republic of Albania as the only socialist state after the Soviet Union under Stalin, who first stated to have achieved socialism with the 1936 Constitution of the Soviet Union.

prompts: States that had communist governments in red , states that the Soviet
baseline: States that had communist governments in red, states that the Soviet Union believed at one point to be moving toward socialism in orange, and states with constitutional references to socialism in yellow

prompts: By the 1960s and 1970s , many Western communist parties had criticized many of the
baseline: By the 1960s and 1970s, many Western communist parties had criticized many of the actions of communist states, distanced from them, and developed a democratic road to socialism, which became known as Eurocommunism.

prompts: With the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the Fall of Communism , there was a split between
baseline: With the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the Fall of Communism, there was a split between those hardline Communists, sometimes referred to in the media as neo-Stalinists, who remained committed to orthodox Marxism–Leninism, and those, such as The Left in Germany, who work within the liberal-democratic process for a democratic road to socialism; other ruling Communist parties became closer to democratic socialist and social-democratic parties.

prompts: For Leninist communism , such goals , including short - term
baseline: For Leninist communism, such goals, including short-term proletarian interests to improve their political and material conditions, can only be achieved through vanguardism, an elitist form of socialism from above that relies on theoretical analysis to identify proletarian interests rather than consulting the proletarians themselves, as is advocated by libertarian communists.

prompts: Marxism considers itself to be the embodiment of scientific socialism but does not model an ideal society
baseline: Marxism considers itself to be the embodiment of scientific socialism but does not model an ideal society based on the design of intellectuals, whereby communism is seen as a state of affairs to be established based on any intelligent design; rather, it is a non-idealist attempt at the understanding of material history and society, whereby communism is the expression of a real movement, with parameters that are derived from actual life.

prompts: The teachings about this society are called " socialism "
baseline: The teachings about this society are called "socialism".

prompts: Leninist revolutionary leadership is based upon The Communist Manifesto ( 1848 ) , identifying the Communist party
baseline: Leninist revolutionary leadership is based upon The Communist Manifesto (1848), identifying the Communist party as "the most advanced and resolute section of the working class parties of every country; that section which pushes forward all others." As the vanguard party, the Bolsheviks viewed history through the theoretical framework of dialectical materialism, which sanctioned political commitment to the successful overthrow of capitalism, and then to instituting socialism; and as the revolutionary national government, to realize the socio-economic transition by all means.

prompts: It also contains aspects which according
baseline: It also contains aspects which according to some are deviations from Marxism such as socialism in one country.

prompts: Marxism – Leninism has been criticized by other communist and Marxist tendencies , which state that Marxist – Leninist states did not establish socialism but rather
baseline: Marxism–Leninism has been criticized by other communist and Marxist tendencies, which state that Marxist–Leninist states did not establish socialism but rather state capitalism.

prompts: Trotskyism , developed by Leon Trotsky in opposition to Stalinism , is a Marxist and
baseline: Trotskyism, developed by Leon Trotsky in opposition to Stalinism, is a Marxist and Leninist tendency that supports the theory of permanent revolution and world revolution rather than the two-stage theory and Stalin's socialism in one country.

prompts: Trotsky 's politics differed sharply from those of Stalin and Mao , most importantly in declaring the need for
baseline: Trotsky's politics differed sharply from those of Stalin and Mao, most importantly in declaring the need for an international proletarian revolution – rather than socialism in one country – and support for a true dictatorship of the proletariat based on democratic principles.

prompts: Along with anarchism , libertarian Marxism is one of the
baseline: Along with anarchism, libertarian Marxism is one of the main derivatives of libertarian socialism.

prompts: It continues today as a
baseline: It continues today as a theoretical and activist position within both libertarian Marxism and libertarian socialism.

prompts: Council communists oppose the perceived authoritarian and undemocratic nature of central planning and of state socialism , labelled state capitalism ,
baseline: Council communists oppose the perceived authoritarian and undemocratic nature of central planning and of state socialism, labelled state capitalism, and the idea of a revolutionary party, since council communists believe that a revolution led by a party would necessarily produce a party dictatorship.

prompts: Anarcho - communism differs from Marxism in that it rejects its view about
baseline: Anarcho-communism differs from Marxism in that it rejects its view about the need for a state socialism phase prior to establishing communism.

prompts: Proponents posit an alleged link
baseline: Proponents posit an alleged link between communism, left-wing politics, and socialism with genocide, mass killing, and totalitarianism.

prompts: Communism encompasses a variety of schools of thought , which broadly include Marxism , Leninism
baseline: Communism encompasses a variety of schools of thought, which broadly include Marxism, Leninism, and libertarian communism, as well as the political ideologies grouped around those.

prompts: In the 20th century , several ostensibly Communist governments espousing Marxism – Leninism
baseline: In the 20th century, several ostensibly Communist governments espousing Marxism–Leninism and its variants came into power, first in the Soviet Union with the Russian Revolution of 1917, and then in portions of Eastern Europe, Asia, and a few other regions after World War II.

prompts: Communism came to be primarily associated with Marxism , most specifically embodied in The Communist
baseline: Communism came to be primarily associated with Marxism, most specifically embodied in The Communist Manifesto, which proposed a particular type of communism.

prompts: A distinction between communist and socialist as descriptors of political ideologies arose in 1918 after
baseline: A distinction between communist and socialist as descriptors of political ideologies arose in 1918 after the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party renamed itself as the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, which resulted in the adjective Communist being used to refer to socialists who supported the politics and theories of Bolshevism, Leninism, and later in the 1920s those of Marxism–Leninism.

prompts: The notion that ' socialism ' and ' Communism ' are distinct historical stages is alien to his
baseline: The notion that 'socialism' and 'Communism' are distinct historical stages is alien to his work and only entered the lexicon of Marxism after his death." According to the Encyclopædia Britannica, "Exactly how communism differs from socialism has long been a matter of debate, but the distinction rests largely on the communists' adherence to the revolutionary socialism of Karl Marx."

prompts: The emergence of the Soviet Union as the world 's first nominally Communist state led to the term
baseline: The emergence of the Soviet Union as the world's first nominally Communist state led to the term's widespread association with Marxism–Leninism and the Soviet-type economic planning model.

prompts: After the Bolshevik defeat , Lenin started referring to the
baseline: After the Bolshevik defeat, Lenin started referring to the assembly as a "deceptive form of bourgeois-democratic parliamentarianism." Some argued this was the beginning of the development of vanguardism as an hierarchical party–elite that controls society, which resulted in a split between anarchism and Marxism, and Leninist communism assuming the dominant position for most of the 20th century, excluding rival socialist currents.

prompts: Mao charged that Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev was the leader of a " revisionist clique " which had turned against Marxism and
baseline: Mao charged that Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev was the leader of a "revisionist clique" which had turned against Marxism and Leninism and was now setting the stage for the restoration of capitalism.

prompts: There were also many developments
baseline: There were also many developments in libertarian Marxism, especially during the 1960s with the New Left.

prompts: With the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the Fall of Communism , there was a split between
baseline: With the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the Fall of Communism, there was a split between those hardline Communists, sometimes referred to in the media as neo-Stalinists, who remained committed to orthodox Marxism–Leninism, and those, such as The Left in Germany, who work within the liberal-democratic process for a democratic road to socialism; other ruling Communist parties became closer to democratic socialist and social-democratic parties.

prompts: The dominant forms of communism are based on Marxism or
baseline: The dominant forms of communism are based on Marxism or Leninism but non-Marxist versions of communism also exist, such as anarcho-communism and Christian communism, which remain partly influenced by Marxist theories, such as libertarian Marxism and humanist Marxism in particular.

prompts: Marxism is a method of socioeconomic analysis that uses a materialist interpretation
baseline: Marxism is a method of socioeconomic analysis that uses a materialist interpretation of historical development, better known as historical materialism, to understand social class relations and social conflict and a dialectical perspective to view social transformation.

prompts: Marxism considers itself to be the embodiment of scientific socialism but does not model an ideal society
baseline: Marxism considers itself to be the embodiment of scientific socialism but does not model an ideal society based on the design of intellectuals, whereby communism is seen as a state of affairs to be established based on any intelligent design; rather, it is a non-idealist attempt at the understanding of material history and society, whereby communism is the expression of a real movement, with parameters that are derived from actual life.

prompts: While it originates from the works of Marx and Engels , Marxism has developed into many different
baseline: While it originates from the works of Marx and Engels, Marxism has developed into many different branches and schools of thought, with the result that there is now no single definitive Marxist theory.

prompts: Different Marxian schools place a greater emphasis on certain aspects of classical Marxism while rejecting or modifying other
baseline: Different Marxian schools place a greater emphasis on certain aspects of classical Marxism while rejecting or modifying other aspects.

prompts: Marxism – Leninism and its offshoots are the most well
baseline: Marxism–Leninism and its offshoots are the most well-known of these and have been a driving force in international relations during most of the 20th century.

prompts: Classical Marxism is the economic , philosophical , and sociological theories expounded by Marx and
baseline: Classical Marxism is the economic, philosophical, and sociological theories expounded by Marx and Engels as contrasted with later developments in Marxism, especially Leninism and Marxism–Leninism.

prompts: Orthodox Marxism is the body of Marxist thought that emerged after the death
baseline: Orthodox Marxism is the body of Marxist thought that emerged after the death of Marx and which became the official philosophy of the socialist movement as represented in the Second International until World War I in 1914.

prompts: Orthodox Marxism aims to simplify , codify , and systematize
baseline: Orthodox Marxism aims to simplify, codify, and systematize Marxist method and theory by clarifying the perceived ambiguities and contradictions of classical Marxism.

prompts: The philosophy of orthodox Marxism includes the understanding that material development ( advances in technology in the productive forces ) is the primary agent of change in the structure of society and of human social relations and that social systems and their relations ( e.g. feudalism , capitalism , and so on ) become contradictory and inefficient
baseline: The philosophy of orthodox Marxism includes the understanding that material development (advances in technology in the productive forces) is the primary agent of change in the structure of society and of human social relations and that social systems and their relations (e.g. feudalism, capitalism, and so on) become contradictory and inefficient as the productive forces develop, which results in some form of social revolution arising in response to the mounting contradictions.

prompts: As a term , orthodox Marxism represents the methods of
baseline: As a term, orthodox Marxism represents the methods of historical materialism and of dialectical materialism, and not the normative aspects inherent to classical Marxism, without implying dogmatic adherence to the results of Marx's investigations.

prompts: At the root of Marxism is historical materialism , the materialist conception of history which holds that the key
baseline: At the root of Marxism is historical materialism, the materialist conception of history which holds that the key characteristic of economic systems through history has been the mode of production and that the change between modes of production has been triggered by class struggle.

prompts: An important concept in Marxism is socialization , i.e.
baseline: An important concept in Marxism is socialization, i.e. social ownership, versus nationalization.

prompts: Marxism considers the latter as its goal and considers nationalization a tactical
baseline: Marxism considers the latter as its goal and considers nationalization a tactical issue, as state ownership is still in the realm of the capitalist mode of production.

prompts: Marxism – Leninism is a political ideology developed by Joseph Stalin
baseline: Marxism–Leninism is a political ideology developed by Joseph Stalin.

prompts: According to its proponents , it is based on Marxism and
baseline: According to its proponents, it is based on Marxism and Leninism.

prompts: It also contains aspects which according
baseline: It also contains aspects which according to some are deviations from Marxism such as socialism in one country.

prompts: Marxism – Leninism was the official ideology of 20th - century Communist parties ( including Trotskyist ) , and was developed after the death
baseline: Marxism–Leninism was the official ideology of 20th-century Communist parties (including Trotskyist), and was developed after the death of Lenin; its three principles were dialectical materialism, the leading role of the Communist party through democratic centralism, and a planned economy with industrialization and agricultural collectivization.

prompts: Marxism – Leninism is misleading because Marx and Lenin never sanctioned or supported the
baseline: Marxism–Leninism is misleading because Marx and Lenin never sanctioned or supported the creation of an -ism after them, and is revealing because, being popularized after Lenin's death by Stalin, it contained those three doctrinal and institutionalized principles that became a model for later Soviet-type regimes; its global influence, having at its height covered at least one-third of the world's population, has made Marxist–Leninist a convenient label for the Communist bloc as a dynamic ideological order.

prompts: During the Cold War , Marxism – Leninism was the ideology of
baseline: During the Cold War, Marxism–Leninism was the ideology of the most clearly visible communist movement and is the most prominent ideology associated with communism.

prompts: Within Marxism – Leninism , anti - revisionism is a position which
baseline: Within Marxism–Leninism, anti-revisionism is a position which emerged in the 1950s in opposition to the reforms and Khrushchev Thaw of Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev.

prompts: The term Stalinism is also used to describe these positions but
baseline: The term Stalinism is also used to describe these positions but is often not used by its supporters who opine that Stalin practiced orthodox Marxism and Leninism.

prompts: Stalinism represents Stalin 's style of governance as opposed to Marxism –
baseline: Stalinism represents Stalin's style of governance as opposed to Marxism–Leninism, the socioeconomic system and political ideology implemented by Stalin in the Soviet Union, and later adapted by other states based on the ideological Soviet model, such as central planning, nationalization, and one-party state, along with public ownership of the means of production, accelerated industrialization, pro-active development of society's productive forces (research and development), and nationalized natural resources.

prompts: Until the death of Joseph Stalin in 1953 , the Soviet Communist party referred to its own
baseline: Until the death of Joseph Stalin in 1953, the Soviet Communist party referred to its own ideology as Marxism–Leninism–Stalinism.

prompts: Marxism – Leninism has been criticized by other communist and Marxist tendencies , which state that Marxist – Leninist states did not establish socialism but rather
baseline: Marxism–Leninism has been criticized by other communist and Marxist tendencies, which state that Marxist–Leninist states did not establish socialism but rather state capitalism.

prompts: According to Marxism , the dictatorship of the proletariat represents the rule of
baseline: According to Marxism, the dictatorship of the proletariat represents the rule of the majority (democracy) rather than of one party, to the extent that the co-founder of Marxism, Friedrich Engels, described its "specific form" as the democratic republic.

prompts: Whether the proletariat was actually in control of the Marxist – Leninist states is a matter of
baseline: Whether the proletariat was actually in control of the Marxist–Leninist states is a matter of debate between Marxism–Leninism and other communist tendencies.

prompts: To these tendencies , Marxism – Leninism is neither Marxism nor
baseline: To these tendencies, Marxism–Leninism is neither Marxism nor Leninism nor the union of both but rather an artificial term created to justify Stalin's ideological distortion, forced into the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and the Comintern.

prompts: In the Soviet Union , this struggle against Marxism – Leninism was represented by Trotskyism ,
baseline: In the Soviet Union, this struggle against Marxism–Leninism was represented by Trotskyism, which describes itself as a Marxist and Leninist tendency.

prompts: A key difference between Maoism and other forms of Marxism – Leninism is that peasants should
baseline: A key difference between Maoism and other forms of Marxism–Leninism is that peasants should be the bulwark of the revolutionary energy which is led by the working class.

prompts: The synthesis of Marxism – Leninism – Maoism , which builds upon the two
baseline: The synthesis of Marxism–Leninism–Maoism, which builds upon the two individual theories as the Chinese adaption of Marxism–Leninism, did not occur during the life of Mao.

prompts: After de - Stalinization , Marxism – Leninism was kept in the Soviet
baseline: After de-Stalinization, Marxism–Leninism was kept in the Soviet Union, while certain anti-revisionist tendencies like Hoxhaism and Maoism stated that such had deviated from its original concept.

prompts: Its adherents claim that as a unified , coherent higher
baseline: Its adherents claim that as a unified, coherent higher stage of Marxism, it was not consolidated until the 1980s, first being formalized by the Shining Path in 1982.

prompts: Through the experience of the people 's war waged by the party
baseline: Through the experience of the people's war waged by the party, the Shining Path were able to posit Maoism as the newest development of Marxism.

prompts: Libertarian Marxism is a broad range of economic and political philosophies that emphasize the anti -
baseline: Libertarian Marxism is a broad range of economic and political philosophies that emphasize the anti-authoritarian aspects of Marxism.

prompts: Early currents of libertarian Marxism , known as left communism
baseline: Early currents of libertarian Marxism, known as left communism, emerged in opposition to Marxism–Leninism and its derivatives such as Stalinism and Maoism, as well as Trotskyism.

prompts: Libertarian Marxism is also critical of reformist positions such as those held by social democrats
baseline: Libertarian Marxism is also critical of reformist positions such as those held by social democrats.

prompts: Along with anarchism , libertarian Marxism is one of the
baseline: Along with anarchism, libertarian Marxism is one of the main derivatives of libertarian socialism.

prompts: Aside from left communism , libertarian Marxism includes such currents as
baseline: Aside from left communism, libertarian Marxism includes such currents as autonomism, communization, council communism, De Leonism, the Johnson–Forest Tendency, Lettrism, Luxemburgism Situationism, Socialisme ou Barbarie, Solidarity, the World Socialist Movement, and workerism, as well as parts of Freudo-Marxism, and the New Left.

prompts: Moreover , libertarian Marxism has often had a strong influence
baseline: Moreover, libertarian Marxism has often had a strong influence on both post-left and social anarchists.

prompts: Notable theorists of libertarian Marxism have included Antonie Pannekoek ,
baseline: Notable theorists of libertarian Marxism have included Antonie Pannekoek, Raya Dunayevskaya, Cornelius Castoriadis, Maurice Brinton, Daniel Guérin, and Yanis Varoufakis, the latter of whom claims that Marx himself was a libertarian Marxist.

prompts: It continues today as a
baseline: It continues today as a theoretical and activist position within both libertarian Marxism and libertarian socialism.

prompts: Left communists assert positions which they regard as more authentically
baseline: Left communists assert positions which they regard as more authentically Marxist and proletarian than the views of Marxism–Leninism espoused by the Communist International after its first congress (March 1919) and during its second congress (July–August 1920).

prompts: Anarcho - communism differs from Marxism in that it rejects its view about
baseline: Anarcho-communism differs from Marxism in that it rejects its view about the need for a state socialism phase prior to establishing communism.

prompts: Criticism of communism can be divided into two broad categories , namely that criticism of Communist party rule that concerns with the practical aspects of 20th - century Communist states , and criticism of Marxism and communism generally that concerns its principles and
baseline: Criticism of communism can be divided into two broad categories, namely that criticism of Communist party rule that concerns with the practical aspects of 20th-century Communist states, and criticism of Marxism and communism generally that concerns its principles and theory.

baseline: Left communists represent a range of political movements distinct from Marxist–Leninists, whom they largely view as merely the left-wing of capital, from anarcho-communists, some of whom they consider to be internationalist socialists, and from various other revolutionary socialist tendencies, such as De Leonists, whom they tend to see as being internationalist socialists only in limited instances.

prompts: One of the first writers to espouse a belief in
baseline: One of the first writers to espouse a belief in the primitive communism of the past was the Roman Stoic philosopher Seneca who stated," How happy was the primitive age when the bounties of nature lay in common...They held all nature in common which gave them secure possession of the public wealth." Because of this he believed that such primitive societies were the richest as there was no poverty.

prompts: Other Greco - Roman writers that believed in a prehistoric
baseline: Other Greco-Roman writers that believed in a prehistoric humanity that practiced communism include Diodorus Siculus, Virgil, and Ovid.

baseline: Around the late 5th century BC in Ancient Greece, ideas similar to communism were becoming widespread to the extent that they were parodied by the dramatist Aristophanes in his comedy The Assemblywomen in which the women of Athens seize control of the Ecclesia or city government and abolish all private property while making the sharing of women and the collective rearing of children mandatory.

baseline: Around AD 500 in Iran, the Zoroastrian priest and reformist Mazdak purportedly founded a movement preaching religious communism while under the patronage of the Sassanian King Kavad I who initially supported the priest and his reforms, but later had the Mazdakians repressed and Mazdak executed.
